awd_titl_txt: NRT-DESE: Generating, Analyzing, and Understanding Sensory and Sequencing Information--A Trans-Disciplinary Graduate Training Program in Biosensing and Computational Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Biosensing using advanced semiconductor technologies and methods based on next generation DNA sequencing generate information about biological systems at an unprecedented scale.  This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award prepares master's and doctoral students at Colorado State University with the tools to extract meaning from huge amounts of sensor and genomics data.  Through innovative curricula and internships, trainees will learn to handle the new computational, statistical, mathematical, and engineering challenges that biologists, computer scientists,  and engineers are unable to overcome alone. This traineeship program contributes to a new generation of scientists and engineers who are able to tackle complex problems related to large datasets in a variety of disciplines.  Moreover, this program builds a community of university, K-12 schools, community colleges, and industry for a wider participation of effective scientific discovery, teaching, and learning.

Research activities integrated with the training program will address themes critical to advance understanding of some fundamental data-related questions facing biological sciences.  Interdisciplinary teams will tackle research involving biological sensors, detection of microbes, regulation of gene expression, and evolutionary genomics and genome assembly.  Faculty across engineering, life sciences, computer science, mathematics, and statistics will develop a flexible, customizable collection of training modules, to create a training experience personalized for each student regardless of their background.  Trainees will develop the skills and tools to process, analyze, visualize, and understand large datasets from biosensing and next generation DNA sequencing.  Additionally, the program incorporates a wide range of transferrable skills training so that trainees will be well equipped to engage and lead data-centric research within or outside academia.

por.por_cntn:
Biosensing systems at the cellular level and next generation DNA sequencing (NGS) are key technologies to advance our understanding of a large variety of biological processes, allowing scientists to probe biological systems at an unprecedented level. Training future scientists and engineers who will be capable of engaging in design and development of new generations of biosensing systems and in analyzing complex genome data at a scale that is significantly more complexity than existing methods is essential to ensure rapid advancement of these crucial technologies in the future.

Intellectual Merit:

This NRT project focuses on research and education of Generating, Analyzing, and Understanding Sensory and Sequencing Information (GAUSSI). The GAUSSI project incorporates transformative innovation in graduate research and education by creating a curriculum that is flexible and customizable for personalized training of participating trainees; providing transferrable professional skills training; and actively promoting multidisciplinary research activities that cross traditional academic boundaries.  The GAUSSI curriculum builds on the concept of "nanocourses" as an effective way to deliver graduate level contents. The curriculum is a collection of learning modules to bridge knowledge gaps and enable graduate students in different academic disciplines to collaborate on multidisciplinary research more effectively. Transferable skills training and career development activities further enrich trainees’ overall experiences.

Broader Impacts:

In addition to 87 trainees participated in the GAUSSI program, the GAUSSI curriculum has also benefited graduate and undergraduate students outside GAUSSI program in their learning about these important technologies. During the course of the project, 46 trainees participated in a variety of activities in K-12 schools providing mentoring for K-12 students and teachers on STEM topics related to their research. Their outreach activities provided a long-lasting impact on raising awareness of exciting STEM fields among K-12 students as they experienced that science and engineering are exciting things to pursue. 87 refereed journal papers and 47 oral presentations  at national and international conferences disseminating the results of the research work performed by the trainees were published. The research performed by the trainees also resulted in 3 US patent applications with the USPO. The innovative approaches in graduate research and education by the GAUSSI program provide future scientists and engineers in the field of biosensing and next generation sequencing with needed skills to ultimately contribute to our nation’s economic vitality and global competitiveness.

 


Last Modified: 07/07/2022
Modified by: Thomas Chen
